thread.title: Springfield Cars sees profits plummet 'challenging' Brexit year

author: Jonathon Manning
title: Springfield Cars sees profits plummet 'challenging' Brexit year
text:
Business Springfield Cars sees profits plummet 'challenging' Brexit year The North East car dealership saw its profit fall to £179,000 in a year that saw included the Brexit referendum Share Springfield Motors on Durham Road, Gateshead (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) Share Get business   Thank you for subscribing!   
New and used car dealership Springfield Cars saw its profits plummet by 60% last year after suffering a “challenging year”. 
The Washington-headquartered firm saw its operating profit fall from £445,790 to £179,030 for the year ending December 31, 2016. 
Springfield, which sells secondhand cars as well as new Citroen, Fiat and Suzuki vehicles, blamed its poor results on a difficult market and added that the Brexit referendum deterred people from buying new cars. 
In the company accounts, director Ronald Price, who owns more than 75% of the business, said: “Although the new car market as a whole increased by 2.25% in volume terms in 2016, compared with the prior 12 months, with over 2.69m vehicle registrations, the franchises which Springfield represents decreased in the period by 5.2% nationally. This resulted in margins being squeezed in an attempt to maximise sales. Springfield Motors on Durham Road, Gateshead (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
“As the economy continued to grow, and historically low interest rates continued, the uncertainty before and after Brexit affected the demand for new vehicles.” Although the new car market proved difficult, sales of secondhand cars were strong. Volume increased by 14%, while the gross margin grew by 15%. Read More Nissan and other car makers face 'cliff edge' on Brexit, industry warns 
Overall, however, Springfield’s turnover fell by 1.2%, from £47.2m to £46.6m. Profit after tax also fell, from £368,000 to £153,000. 
Springfield increased head count from 95 to 98 at the end of 2016, adding to its staffing costs, which grew from £2.7m to £2.8m. 
The firm’s highest paid director received £145,368 last year, up from £140,298 during the previous year. 
Mr Price added that market conditions during 2017 would likely mirror conditions at the end of 2016, which could lead to more favourable results for the firm. 
He said: “The company strategy is to continue to focus with our current manufacturer partners in our current market, while identifying franchise opportunities within the North East of England. 
“The directors anticipate that the trading environment will continue throughout 2017 in the same as at the end of 2016, with new car registrations remaining high, influenced by pre-registration activity; fleet activity and demand to be high; used cars supply to be challenging and after-sales remaining high.” Like us on Facebook
